title: Watch These Intel Stock Price Levels Amid Tariff-Induced Price Swings
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Intel shares soared Wednesday amid a huge rally for chip stocks after President Trump announced a 90-day pause on many of the tariffs that had rattled financial markets.
  • Wednesday's bullish reversal saw the stock reclaim the September low, potentially setting the stage for follow-through buying.
  • Investors should monitor key overhead areas on Intel's chart near $25 and $35, while also watching a crucial zone of support between $18.50 and $17.


Intel (INTC) shares soared Wednesday amid a huge rally for chip stocks after President Trump announced a 90-day pause on "reciprocal" tariffs.

The stock may also be attracting interest following reports the chipmaker tentatively agreed to form a joint venture with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSM) that would run the U.S. company’s foundry business.

While tariff developments will likely continue to drive near-term sentiment in the stock, confirmation of a potential deal with TSMC that ramps up domestic contract chip manufacturing could act as a catalyst for further upside.

Intel shares have outperformed the S&P 500 since the start of the year as of Wednesday's close, though the stock has lost 44% over the past 12 months amid uncertainty surrounding the chipmaker’s restructuring plans and constant deal speculation. The stock gained 19% on Wednesday to close at $21.53.

Below, we analyze Intel’s monthly chart and apply technical analysis to identify crucial levels that investors may be watching.

Bullish Reversal

After forming a double top between January 2020 and April 2021, Intel shares have trended sharply lower, with a countertrend rally to the 50-month moving average (MA) in December 2023 running into immediate selling pressure.

More recently, bears drove a brief sell-off below last year's September low before bulls reclaimed this key level during Wednesday's bullish reversal, potentially setting the stage for follow-though buying. However, investors should brace for further volatility ahead, with trading volume picking up in the stock since August last year.

Let's identify key overhead areas to monitor and also point out a crucial zone of support worth watching amid the potential for further tariff-driven volatility.

Key Overhead Areas to Monitor

Follow-through buying from current levels could initially see the shares climb to around $25. This area on the chart may provide selling pressure near a trendline that links multiple peaks and troughs on the chart extending back to mid 1997.

Buying above this level could form part of a longer-term bullish reversal to $35. Investors who have bought the stock's recent lows may look to offload shares in this region near the 200-month MA and a multi-year horizontal line the links a range of comparable trading activity on the chart between January 1999 and September 2023.

Crucial Zone of Support Worth Watching

During future moves lower in the stock, investors should keep track of a crucial zone of support on Intel's chart between $18.50 and $17. This region will likely continue to attract significant attention from investors, given it's the location that marked the stock's recent low and sits near a range if similar price points stretching back to the late 90s.

The comments, opinions, and analyses expressed on Investopedia are for informational purposes only. Read our warranty and liability disclaimer for more info.

As of the date this article was written, the author does not own any of the above securities.
summary: Intel shares surged on Wednesday, following President Trump's announcement of a 90-day pause on certain tariffs, contributing to a broader rally in chip stocks. The stock's rise was also fueled by reports of a potential joint venture with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) to enhance U.S. chip manufacturing. Despite a 44% decline over the past year amid restructuring and deal speculation, Intel outperformed the S&P 500 as of Wednesday's close, gaining 19% to finish at $21.53. The stock's recent performance, including a bullish reversal reclaiming September's low, suggests potent
titles: Watch These Intel Stock Price Levels Amid Tariff-Induced Price Swings

title: Why quantum computers may continue to fail a key test
snippets: There have been several claims of quantum computers performing at a level impossible to match with a classical computer – most of which have been refuted. Could there be a mathematical reason why this keeps happening?
summary: Recent discussions have focused on claims that quantum computers have achieved performance levels unattainable by classical computers. Many of these claims have been contested and debunked. The ongoing debate suggests a need to explore if there's a mathematical basis for these recurrent discrepancies in performance claims between quantum and classical computing.
titles: Why quantum computers may continue to fail a key test

titles: World's first baby born by IVF done almost entirely by a machine

title: Eight or more drinks per week linked to signs of injury in the brain
snippets: Heavy drinkers who have eight or more alcoholic drinks per week have an increased risk of brain lesions called hyaline arteriolosclerosis, signs of brain injury that are associated with memory and thinking problems, according to a new study.
summary: A new study has found that heavy drinkers, defined as those consuming eight or more alcoholic drinks weekly, face a higher risk of developing hyaline arteriolosclerosis. This condition, characterized by brain lesions, is linked to memory and thinking issues.
titles: Eight or more drinks per week linked to signs of injury in the brain

title: Plant-based waterproof material could replace single-use plastics
snippets: Cellulose, the main component of paper, can be turned into clear, waterproof objects such as cups that are almost indistinguishable from plastic, but break down more quickly
summary: Researchers have developed a method to transform cellulose, the primary substance in paper, into clear, waterproof objects resembling plastic, such as cups. Unlike traditional plastic, these cellulose-based products have the advantage of decomposing more rapidly, offering a more environmentally friendly alternative.
titles: Plant-based waterproof material could replace single-use plastics

title: What politicians so often get wrong about science
snippets: Governments love asking what scientific research will bring society, but the most important discoveries come from wondering without direction
summary: Scientific research often faces scrutiny from governments regarding its societal benefits. However, significant breakthroughs frequently result from exploratory inquiry without a predetermined objective. This highlights the value of curiosity-driven research beyond immediate practical applications.
titles: What politicians so often get wrong about science
